description.narrative: The support to the Human Rights Commission of Sierra Leone (HRCSL) strengthens the capacity of the institution to enhance human rights promotion, protection and fulfilment by improving internal capacities.

condition.narrative: Social and environmental sustainability will be enhanced through application of the UNDP Social and Environmental Standards (http://www.undp.org/ses) and related Accountability Mechanism (http://www.undp.org/secu-srm).
UNDP as the Implementing Partner will comply with the policies, procedures and practices of the United Nations Security Management System (UNSMS.)

comment.narrative:
Output 1: Staff and Institutional capacity of the HRC is strengthened to effectively deliver on its human rights promotion and protection mandate.  One HRCSL gender responsive Institutional capacity assessment conducted and capacity building plan developed.  HRCSL Act, 2004 amended and Updated.  Fourth HRC Strategic Plan (2021-2024) developed and adopted; 400 copies of the new Act printed and disseminated.  25 HRCSL personnel, 70 MDAs and 24 DHRC TOT trained (disaggregated by gender).  A 2-day national consultative conference on UPR involving 80 persons (disaggregated by gender and category of participants) organised.
Output 2: Strengthened public awareness and empowerment of rights-holders to hold government accountable to their human rights commitment.  12 radio-based human rights hour programmes conducted in 2020  9 human rights school outreach conducted and # of boys and girl participating in 9 HRPC established

Output 1: Staff and Institutional capacity of the HRC is strengthened to effectively deliver on its human rights promotion and protection mandate.
 28 (M20, F8) HRCSL personnel (5 new Commissioners and 23 staff), benefitted from training in March 2020, on national and international human rights frameworks and mechanisms, complaint handling, gender issues and resource mobilisation. The training exceeded target by 3 (12%) additional beneficiaries. Post-training evaluation suggested transfer of knowledge.
 70 (M50, F20) CSO and MDAs representatives benefitted from training on the UPR process and reporting on the SDGs and African Vision conducted on 17 and 18 March 2020 in Port Loko and Kenema respectively. Target achieved.
 42 (M33, F9) members of the DHRCs benefitted from TOT on the treaty body reporting process, complaints handling and investigation, resource mobilization, gender and human rights and ADR mechanisms. Target for TOT for District Human Rights Committees exceeded by 75%.
 1 HRCSL Gender responsive capacity assessment report produced, and 1 capacity building plan developed.
 1 HRCSL gender responsive strategic plan (2021-2025) developed, validated and launched.
 1 HRCSL Act 2004 reviewed by a Technical Working Group (TWG) and set the stage for subsequent amendment.  6 Honda XL125 Motorbikes procured and this has helped in enhancing the human rights outreach capacity of the Commission.
 3 consultative conferences on the UPR involving 80 (M64, F16) stakeholders including CSO, MDAs, Local councils, academics, security personnel, traditional authorities organised at regional and national levels.
 90 (M65, F25) law enforcement officers benefitted from 2 regional trainings on rights-based approach and NaCOVERC’s SOPs in responding to COVI-19.
 49 (from M32, F17) complaints were received and processed, 10 resolved, 4 mediated, 3 are currently being investigated, 15 referred to various MDAs and are being closely monitored, and 9 pending.
Output 2: Strengthened public awareness and empowerment of rights-holders (women/girls and men/boys)to hold government accountable to their human rights commitment.
 Conducted 9 regular radio discussion programmes and 876 jingle slots aired four local languages in 14 community radios and press releases to raise public awareness on COVID-19 pandemic across the country COVID-19 and Human Rights.
 Nine (9) schools participated in the training session leading to the establishment of 9 Human Rights Peace Clubs. A total number of 50 beneficiaries which comprised 36 pupils and 14 teachers (27 male and 23 female) benefitted from the training conducted in the Western Urban. The training was based on basic concepts of human rights, the mandate of the Human Rights Commission of Sierra Leone and the UDHR. Target achieved.

Output 1: Staff and Institutional capacity of the HRC is strengthened to effectively deliver on its human rights promotion and protection mandate.
1. At least 1 Institutional capacity assessment conducted 2. HRCSL capacity building plan developed. 3. At least 1 training targeting 25 participants conducted. 4. One (1) study-tours to NHRI in Uganda involving 6 staff undertaken. 5. Four 4 monthly HRWG meeting meetings held. 6. One (1) SOHR 2018 developed, launched and published. 7. At least 300 copies of SOHR printed and disseminated. 8. At least 1 quarterly Referral partnership fora held. 9. At least 1 mobile complaint hearings held at regional level.
Output 2: Strengthened public awareness and empowerment of rights-holders to hold government accountable to their human rights commitment.
1. Four (4) advocacy activities conducted as part of celebration of international Human Rights Day 10 Dec 2019 with an estimated 190 direct right-holders beneficiaries. 2. At least 8 bi-monthly radio-based human rights hour programmes conducted. 3. At least 3 Human rights awareness outreach to 3 secondary schools conducted and human rights and peace clubs established.

 Senior Rule of Law and Human Rights Officer hired to work with the Human Rights Commission  An international consultant recruited to conduct a comprehensive capacity assessment, develop a capacity building plan and train the newly appointed Commissioners.  A study-tour conducted to Uganda benefitted 7 (5 male and 2 female) personnel who had the opportunity to learn and understand some best practices and uniqueness of the UHRC with regards to key functional areas which strengthen protection and promotion of human rights.  A total of 3 (75%) out of four monthly HRWG meetings were held.  The SOHR 2018 developed and 400 (33% increase) copies printed for dissemination.  One (1) Referral Partnership Meeting was held with 21 (17 male and 4 female) representatives of various institutions. The updates from nine (9) complaints under review indicated that 44% of complaints referred to partners were successfully resolved and 56% were still pending investigation  One (1) mobile complaint hearing and human rights awareness raising session was held in Ngiehun Konjo in the Malegohun Chiefdom. The HRCSL sought the release of 10 underage girls forcefully initiated into FGM, mediated and resolved the one (1) case of deprivation of property and referred six (6) to other institutions for remedy.  The HRCSL organised two (2) activities, a float parade and inter-junior secondary school quiz competition as part of the celebration of the International Human Rights Day under the localized theme: ‘Stand up for Human Rights and Fight against Sexual and Gender Based Violence’  A total of 17 (113% increase) human rights-based radio awareness programmes were undertaken in four districts. Also included three jingles developed in the three main local languages. Approximately 50 phone-in calls were made on the Sexual Offenses Act 2019 as amended. An estimated 1000 people including 50% male and 50% female benefitted.  10 Human rights outreach to senior secondary schools conducted with 51 (26 boys and 25 girls) beneficiaries and 10 Human Rights Peace Clubs established, five (5) in Bo and five (5) in Kenema in 2019.
